body: @kchibisov I wonder if there's a reasonable way to include a valgrind run like this in our benchmarks/tests? This should ideally be something we watch automatically for regressions.

issue.title: Fix excessive allocations in URL parser

body:
I think https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/pull/3006 should fix this. Since the `RenderableCell` implements `Copy`, I've decided to just create a single buffer which stores all the scheme cells. I have not yet verified it though and will not be able to run valgrind on it until tomorrow. But I'm optimistic.

I've also added some much needed tests, so hopefully that should help with future refactorings too.

> I wonder if there's a reasonable way to include a valgrind run like this in our benchmarks/tests? This should ideally be something we watch automatically for regressions.

This would probably be easier than benchmarks, however I'm not sure how much sense it makes. It's questionable to me if we should really be watching valgrind so heavily unless there's an actual issue created as a result of it. However this issue provides some evidence that it is necessary.

I think I'd recommend not jumping to conclusions from this and going forward with the occasional valgrind run. Then if we should notice that this is something that would be useful to have automated, we can put the effort into automating it. But so far I don't think there's a need for it, great idea to keep in mind though.

Agreed, I'm not demanding that we (or you) do this now urgently, just given how @kchibisov seems to be keen on checking, I thought I'd float it past this thread.

Also, related issue in tensorflow/rust#69

issue.title: Document causes frozen terminal, 100% CPU
issue.body:
If I run `curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/miloyip/nativejson-benchmark/master/data/canada.json`, the terminal becomes unresponsive and consumes 100% of CPU. It may at first be responsive, stalling after ~10s, or with -vvv becomes unresponsive sometimes before it finishes rendering the file.

Memory usage is unchanged. It seems to consume CPU indefinitely. 

The file is a ~2MiB JSON document of mostly floats. There are no formatting characters in it.

This is on alacritty 0.3.0 and current HEAD (ab8fddd5938024beca3a97eab9022db07f675a3c) on Linux and macOS with default configuration.

With alacritty -vvv here are two different logs:
